In the second edition of In Conversation, Kunal Chatterjee, Head of Acceptance Sales for VAS at Visa Asia Pacific spoke with Sisca Margaretta Elliott about what he believes has changed dramatically about payments in the last few years: how people pay, and in turn, how merchants accept payments. 

The way people transact today is diverse and omnichannel: with a tap of their cards, mobile phones, and wearables like smartwatches. Currencies are also evolving with digital currencies, gaming credits, and more becoming part of the fabric of digital transactions.

How can merchants accept new forms of payments regardless of methods, form factors, and borders in a fast, secure, and reliable way? 

This is what matters to Visa. In particular, the Visa Acceptance Platform enables merchants across Asia Pacific to accept digital payments from all major card networks, be it tapping or swiping in person or even virtually in card-not-present scenarios with a single API integration. 

Along with Visaâ€™s 99.999% network uptime and Visa-grade security trusted by millions worldwide, merchants can enjoy best-in-class digital acceptance with peace of mind â€“ today and tomorrow. 

Listen to the conversation in full: https://vi.sa/4ruzYoC

Last week, Visa announced the renewal of our partnership with CJ ENM - extending our title sponsorship of the MAMA AWARDS to 2029.

Megaevents are engines of commerce and culture in Asia Pacific and the MAMA AWARDS is more than an awards ceremony. It is a cultural touchstone for Visa to engage a new generation of consumers and let K-pop fans everywhere be the fans they want to be.

Ahead of Worldâ€™s International Education Day on 24 January, weâ€™re celebrating how education and skills-building create pathways to opportunity for individuals, communities, and economies across Asia Pacific.

From community learning spaces in India to financial education in Hong Kong and a financial literacy program for women in Fiji, Visa is advancing inclusive growth by equipping people with the skills they need to thrive in a digital economy.

In India, our partnership with Read India has expanded four Community Library and Resource Centres across Karnataka, supporting 1,950 women and youths with education, digital literacy and job-ready skills since 2024 - helping women build livelihoods and children develop confidence to learn and lead.

In Hong Kong, Visa supports the Hong Kong Financial Literacy Championship, an 11-year partnership with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and Hong Kong Education Bureau. The largest student competition of its kind in the Greater Bay Area, the programme has reached 92% of Hong Kongâ€™s secondary schools. Its latest edition engaged 19,800 students from over 300 schools, combining financial knowledge, fintech innovation, and mentorship to prepare young people for a rapidly evolving digital economy.

In Fiji, Visa partnered with Good Return to deliver the Consumer Awareness and Financial Empowerment (CAFE) program in Serua Province â€” a multi-week learning journey in financial capability and behavioural change for women in the underserved communities. Delivered by 21 trained coaches and reaching over 190 participants, the program drove measurable impact, including increased trust in mobile financial services, stronger money-management behaviours, and a sharp reduction in financial stress.

At Visa, we believe education is a powerful driver of inclusive growth. When learning is accessible, people prosper and economies move forward. Thatâ€™s why weâ€™re committed to expanding opportunities so everyone, everywhere can learn, grow, and thrive. 

Discover how Visaâ€™s social impact programs are expanding access to education, financial literacy and opportunity around the world: https://vi.sa/457fA4u

Cybersecurity continues to be one of Visaâ€™s highest priorities as Indonesiaâ€™s digital economy grows rapidly. With emerging technologies transforming how people transact, the risks are evolving just as quickly. Protecting consumers, businesses, and the broader payments ecosystem requires constant vigilance, crossâ€‘sector partnership, and a shared commitment to staying ahead of increasingly sophisticated threats. 

Against this backdrop, Visa was honored to join the US-ASEAN Business Council on the highâ€‘level workshop, â€œStrengthening Indonesiaâ€™s Digital Future: Advancing Cybersecurity in the Age of Emerging Technologies.â€ The discussion underscored the importance of collective action to ensure security, resilience, and trust as digital adoption accelerates nationwide. 

We were privileged to contribute through remarks by Mr. Abdul Rahim, Southeast Asia, Head of Risk at Visa, who highlighted the rise of AIâ€‘driven cyber threats and outlined strategies to strengthen digital payment security across Indonesia. We also welcomed keynote insights from Mr. Albert Rachmad Wibowo, Deputy Head of Badan Siber dan Sandi Negara; Ambassador Peter M. Haymond, ChargÃ© dâ€™Affaires ad interim, U.S. Embassy Jakarta; and Ms. Lilian Rogers, Head of Government Affairs ASEAN at Cisco, who emphasized unlocking ASEANâ€™s digital future through cybersecurity, AI, infrastructure, and Quantum Computing. 

At Visa, we remain deeply committed to working handâ€‘inâ€‘hand with policymakers, regulators, financial institutions, and industry partners. We recognize that safeguarding Indonesiaâ€™s digital ecosystem is a shared responsibility, and we are grateful for the trust and collaboration that make this work possible. By strengthening partnerships and openly sharing threat intelligence, we aim to contribute to a more secure digital environment, one that protects users and supports Indonesiaâ€™s ongoing innovation and economic growth. 

Our sincere thanks to the USâ€‘ASEAN Business Council, all speakers, and every participant for contributing to this meaningful dialogue. We look forward to deepening our partnerships to advance a safer and more inclusive digital future.
